text:
Last year I volunteered with TEDxSanFrancisco last year to lead their email marketing campaigns, and this year I'm trying to develop an overarching digital editorial strategy.

Although I don't work in the event space, I managed to leverage this volunteering to get my current role at eBay.

In my interview, the interviewer pulled up my portfolio and long story short, by chance they saw my after party promo email with the heading "Better Than Saturday Night Fever," which (intentionally) was sent on a Saturday.

She absolutely loved the piece and we talked about the results of the campaign on ticket sales.

Although TEDx has nothing to do with eCommerce or my work at eBay, I'm confident that I got my current position because I was able to use the email campaign as an example of how I approach work. And then I applied it to eBay's challenges.

In my experience, I've found that companies really care about your ability to pick up knowledge and translate details into engaging material. For legal and bioscience, then domain expertise is absolutely required, but I think for other niches, you just need to show interest and ability to rapidly learn.

text: <@URL9Z88MR> I had a similar experience with a client.
